review_title: All the good and the bad
pros:
- Promotes Healthy office culture
- A lot how you work depends on your Manager. Everything is good until your manager is able to handle people skills and technical skills. If the manager is incompetent, everything else falls apart.
- Good Learning and growth
- Some projects follow strict Hierarchical Management and with some you can just walk in and discuss your feedback, expectations and issues face to face.
- Highly motivates you to grow your career and leadership skills.
- Establish a trust relationship with peers, a friendly environment with continuous Team building activities.
cons:
- Top Management decisions are not transparent to team members.
- Project may shutdown at any time without prior notice or indication even though they have a roadmap for two years to come.
- Unpredictable Business growth. 
- Lack in the use of latest technology and frameworks.

Even having re-planned multiple times and retroactive reduction of comissions earned AFTER THE END of the fiscal year. All your hard earned work just goes to their bottom line so they can make their numbers. Also super shady practices and cheating on financials like signing agreements with companies where the company has no intention of implementing solutions but signs on with loopholes to get discounts on other software. In addition the amount I was offered initially for salary got reduced and they required me to send in my W-2s which I found out later was completely illegal. Such a shady company.

review_title: Oracle great company, but not for everyone
pros:
Stable job
Proper 9-5 job
Hire really smart people
Very good starting job with a huge branding.
BDC is the first step into doing sales, but can't be stuck in this role for too long.
Take the opportunity to learn about Oracle portfolio. Like it or not, they are one of the biggest corporation and there's a reason why.
A lot of learning platform internally with a lot of helpful teammates.
Huge investment towards the cloud, cutting edge technologies
Great valuable certification from Oracle which is great for any future employment
cons:
Coming from the BDC perspective, the BDC title is actually telemarketing. So don't be too excited thinking you are doing any "business development". Your job is just to pick up phone and call. Not much of a rocket science there. They hire graduates in pretense of learning sales, but you are basically cheap labor to pick up call, as career progression is really difficult here. 

From telemarketing, you basically move to another telemarketing role + sales closure. The BDC is constantly at risk of losing their value since there's not much ROI coming from this business unit, since their job is just demand gen. 

Also there are lots of office politics going on, since everyone needs to keep their job. While doing your job, you need to be able to manage politics as well.

review_title: It could be a really good company to work for. Unless you end up in a toxic environment
pros: Good networking; if you are good, other well established companies will try to head hunt you; possibility to change team/Lob; solid company; they have an office in Malaga, a paradise in terms of quality of life; good products (PaaS and IaaS are becoming to get noticed)
cons:
It seems that senior leaders at Oracle are closing both eyes on bad sales practices. Also, despite all their claims of being against gender discrimination, and wanting to support women, I witnessed several woman that after becoming mum, the senior manager took away the good customers/territories from her, and she does not receive any "congratulations" message from the company either (if she is lucky, her manager and co-workers will send it to her).
Targets are really high and far from being achievable (I guess this is the way they keep costs down). Career promotion is unclear (I once saw the partner of a manager being promoted, while other sales reps with better performance were not).
Not saying every manager/director is toxic. Not at all! I had the luxury to meet both types during my several years at Oracle Digital in Malaga. Good luck.

cons: This is where the hit or miss comes into play. Some managers are fantastic and you'd be really fortunate to be on their team and be mentored by them. Other managers are really toxic and just plain awful. The 401K match and stock purchase plan left a lot to be desired considering the profitability of the company. The org structure is all over the place; there's little consistency across accounts, making it really difficult to know who to turn to and where responsibilities lie.

pros: Good benefits, they won't ever fire you

The Portuguese language team have only 4 people to cover all hotels in Brazil and Portugal. They don't give you training that it will be useful for your work, they will expect you to learn the entire system in one week (Including fiscal rules for the different countries) and will put you in front of computer to get calls straight away with the same goals of the other members of the team who are working there for years. Many managers from US will shame you sending emails for all the teams around the world, copying all the managers, asking you to be available in the phone even if you already got more than 20 calls and you are about to finish your shift. Do not expect to have a career opportunity, because it doesn't happen for employers who start working on L1 of support.

job_title: Applications Sales Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Innovative company, the best cloud platform in the market, so many resources to help you sell.
cons: Big company feel. No real focus on employee culture. Too many leadership changes in the last three years especially in HCM applications. Get used to change at the start of every fiscal and about every 3 years highly disruptive change to employees and customers. Not a lot of rigor from leadership team or sales operations to ensure some margin of equity in account assignments. If you don’t get a good territory each fiscal year change, there’s really no appetite from leadership to add or modify account assignments despite what might be communicated. Therefore, use caution when negotiating your base salary and discussing OTE variable earnings. Sometimes it really is the luck of the draw with account assignments and many, many examples of reps not having a realistic opportunity to earn variable based on limited territory size, long sales cycles, etc.

review_title: A great place to build and sustain your career
pros:
Oracle has built/ acquired market-leading products and services so it's a cash-rich company. Many people have made good money, especially at Cloud division. 
Work-life balance is very good with some pressure during releases, but that's common across the software industry.
cons:
Oracle India is different from overall Oracle and is highly dependent on Oracle US for directions and hence the hierarchy is not very successful.
There's a huge salary difference at the same level for cloud and application employees, which is not good for growth and attrition is high in both areas.
There was no one-off allowance for home setup which was given across a lot of other companies.
The other departments like admin, HR, etc. are lull and have a very little say in your work-life which might be good, but it takes long time to get stuff done.

job_title: Senior Technical Program Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Many of the pros have dissolved in the past two years with the pandemic. There's not much left. The company has really gone downhill.
cons: Benefits eliminated since the start of the pandemic: professional development budget, morale budget, the fun with happy hours and stickers and such, ability to order supplies to do your job, etc. I haven't had an increase of compensation for the last two years. Work is more intense, longer, and it never seems like enough. You might have a great team or a great manager if you're lucky, but Oracle does not care about or support their people. And if you're unlucky, you have a crappy team, manager, and everything. Getting out as soon as I can. I recruited friends and colleagues to join pre-pandemic. Now I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

job_title: Business Development Consultant in Austin, TX
pros: Oracle is a great company to start right out of college. It holds a lot of power in the tech world, especially if you are coming in with a non-business/tech background. You learn a lot about technology and business operations on the job.
cons: The sales department at Oracle is very disorganized. "The only constant is change" is the tagline, but seems like an excuse because they can't get things in order. This is especially true for the lower/entry level sales jobs outside of the field sales rep.

job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros: I haven't seen any pros, cons are as follows
cons:
Well here the list goes on

Oracle in general,
1. Not an employee friendly company
2. No open door policy
3. "Transparency" does not exist in their dictionary

Things that I have observed
1. Alarmingly outdated technology
2. Those who are staying here for long time are known for their arrogance as well as stupidity
3. Managers are high paying idiots, they have no clue what's going on in the project, what are the challenges, whether the code is of good quality. They are just bothered about number of code changes getting merged so that they can use it as a trump card of their promotion

4. Managers (onwards) are there just to warm their seats and to shout at their subordinates for no reason, now a days trends are changing, managers are becoming engineering managers. But Oracle managers are happy to remain as good for nothing leeches.

5. No hike or bonus for atleast 2-3 years no matter how much you put.
6. In the end, there is no learning only meaningless slogging

job_title: Business Development Representative in Burlington, MA
pros: Great people and community culture. They adapted to a fully remote working environment exceptionally well. Decent pay for an entry level job. You will learn A TON about how to find success in sales. The sales org is growing leaps and bounds and there is a lot of opportunity for advancement.
cons:
Sales org structure changes all the time and without warning. Territories change often which is a symptom of growth but it can be stressful when it seems to happen so suddenly. Hours are supposed to be 8:30-5:30 but realistically if you want to hit quota and have success you will find yourself working extra hours. There is rarely an opportunity to earn overtime pay, although I have in the past on occasion
The job can be tedious after a while and burnout is likely. It’s good to keep in mind that the entry level program leads to better opportunities down the line.
